channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Eurozone Industrial Production Swings Back to Decline
item.description: Output fell 1.2% in August on month, a reflection of uncertainty among manufacturing firms as they adapt to reshaped global trade.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Upset over higher food prices, consumers are cutting back on purchases, stockpiling certain items or exploring more-affordable stores
item.description: Shoppers say they are cutting back on purchases, stockpiling certain foods or exploring more-affordable stores.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: China’s Deflationary Pressures Ease Slightly
item.description: Downward price pressures eased in September, but not quite as much as expected, as Beijing ramps up efforts to curb excess capacity and bolster domestic demand.

item.title: Fed Chair Powell left the central bank on track to reduce rates again at this month’s meeting and suggested it could be close to ending a campaign to passively reduce its $6.6 trillion asset holdings
item.description: The central-bank leader also suggested the Fed could be close to ending a three-year campaign to passively reduce its $6.6 trillion asset holdings.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: China’s Rare-Earth Export Controls Are ‘Critical Concern’ for EU, Trade Chief Says
item.description: Maros Sefcovic said the measures were causing a lot of problems for European companies, as tensions continue to rise between Brussels and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: U.K. Unemployment Edges Higher
item.description: The labor market loosened a little in the three months through August, with unemployment creeping up and wage growth slowing, as firms continued to hold back from hiring.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: U.K. Economy Faces Rising Risk Of a ‘Hard Landing,’ Says BOE’s Taylor
item.description: Rate-setter Alan Taylor said there is a small but growing possibility that the U.K. economy is heading for recession, due in part to overly high borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Small-Business Sentiment Declines Slightly as Uncertainty Persists
item.description: Enduring inflationary pressures and labor shortages add to growing uncertainty about the economy.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Singapore Central Bank Stands Pat as Economy Shows Resilience, But Risks Loom
item.description: The Monetary Authority of Singapore held monetary policy steady as it balanced better-than-expected economic growth against rising risks from tariffs and inflation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Cheah

item.title: Cautious RBA in No Rush to Cut Rates Further
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia said future policy decisions will remain dependent on the flow of economic data.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: Federal Reserve Can Look Through Tariff-Driven Inflation, Fed’s Paulson Says
item.description: Price increases driven by tariffs will likely prove temporary, according to Philadelphia Fed President Anna Paulson, who also threw her support behind further interest-rate cuts this year as the Fed responds to a slowing labor market.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: China’s Exports Rise at Fastest Pace in Six Months Despite U.S. Tariffs
item.description: China’s exports rose at the fastest pace in six months in September, beating market expectations and underscoring the sector’s continued role as a key growth driver for the world’s second-largest economy.

item.title: China was already seeing economic momentum slow before Trump announced the latest 100% tariff increase, part of a trade-war flare-up that Beijing on Sunday blamed on the U.S.
item.description: Beijing was already seeing growth slow before Trump announced the latest 100% tariff increase, part of a trade-war flare-up that China has blamed on the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: The man who won a record Powerball jackpot has a new goal: redevelop his hometown after the L.A. fires
item.description: Edwin Castro is one of the biggest investors snapping up destroyed properties—and he wants to lead in rebuilding his hometown of Altadena.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: South Korea’s Hanwha Group is pledging to revive the U.S. shipbuilding industry, but it won’t happen soon
item.description: Hanwha has said two ships on order will be made almost entirely in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Costas Paris

item.title: A California new law to make it easier for developers to build multistory apartment buildings near major commuter stops, has triggered fierce opposition from Los Angeles and other coastal cities
item.description: Gov. Newsom Friday signed a bill that will make it easier to build apartment buildings. Cities like Los Angeles fear a loss of control.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: President Trump’s tariff rollout has taken numerous twists and turns since launching earlier this year. Here’s a roundup of where things stand.
item.description: A roundup of where things stand with tariffs on key U.S. trade partners and sectors.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Holds Steady in October
item.description: Economic sentiment remained grim but held steady near recent levels in October as a federal shutdown hampered government functions and sidelined thousands of workers, according to the University of Michigan’s latest consumer survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Exports Unexpectedly Fell in August as Uncertainty Weighed
item.description: Exports of goods fell 0.5% on month, hampered by weaker trade with other European nations and the uncertainty prompted by U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: IMF Chief Sees Global Growth Slowing ‘Only Slightly’ in Face of Higher Tariffs
item.description: The global economy is holding up better than expected in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries and the implications of technological change, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: A small drop in mortgage rates in recent weeks triggered an outsize response from borrowers
item.description: A small drop in rates in recent weeks has triggered an outsize response from borrowers.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: A host of alternative jobs data from Wall Street are pointing in the same direction: The U.S. labor market is losing steam
item.description: In a federal data blackout, Wall Street numbers and surveys are filling the void, and the nongovernment numbers are telling the same basic story: Few companies are hiring.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Federal-Worker Buyouts Are Kicking In, Darkening the U.S. Employment Picture
item.description: About 100,000 federal workers came off the payroll last week, adding strain to an already weakening labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Unboxing the thrill of Labubus, or why so many young consumers are spending big on blind boxes
item.description: Getting hold of Labubus and other blind-box toys is a game of odds; the thrill of the surprise keeps young consumers coming back for more.
item.dc:creator: Audrey Valbuena

item.title: The monthly jobs numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics won’t arrive on time because of the government shutdown. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.description: The monthly government jobs numbers didn’t arrive on time. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: The U.S. shed 32,000 private-sector jobs in September, payroll processing giant ADP said
item.description: The ADP private-sector jobs report showed a labor force that continues to deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up Pace as ECB Looks Set to Keep Rates on Hold
item.description: European Central Bank rate setters are sanguine about potential pressures on prices and expect last month’s rise in inflation to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: BOE Deputy Governor Sees Inflation Resuming Fall After ‘Hump’
item.description: The recent pickup in inflation, which is projected to hit 4% this month before declining, is unlikely to have long-lasting consequences, said Sarah Breeden.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Labor-Turnover Was Steady in August
item.description: The rate of layoffs in the economy was mostly steady at 1.1% from July. Hiring was largely steady as well, with the rate of new job offers holding at 3.2%.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Inflation Risks Are ‘Contained’
item.description: Eurozone inflation is unlikely to rise much above, or fall much below, the European Central Bank’s target despite a reshaping of global trade, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Continued to Cool Ahead of Fed’s Rate Cut
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.7% in the 12 months through July, down from 1.9% on year in June and continuing a run of the weakest price rises since July 2023.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Heard on the Street: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business
item.description: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: BOE Has Scope for Careful and Gradual Rate Cuts, Says Ramsden
item.description: The Bank of England can continue to lower its key interest rate while bringing inflation down to its 2% target, deputy governor Dave Ramsden said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending
item.description: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: German Consumers Feel Ever Gloomier as Economy Slumps
item.description: Concerns around unemployment drove the cautious mood among German shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby
